captions.text:
bjbjLULU Episode 37: Game Show Theory Hello
Internet. Welcome to Game Theory, or should

I say Game Show Theory. Because gaming isn
t just limited to consoles and controllers,

and while, yes, it may be interesting to know
that Jynx isn t racist, chances are it won

t help you win A BRAND NEW CAR! So this week,
we re entering a world of fabulous prizes

and gaudy suits, a world of Bobs, from Barker
to Eubanks, with more Rods and Winks and Dicks

than you can shake a skinny microphone at.
So start pricing up your turtle wax and Rice-a-Roni,

Joe Millionaires, because this week I m teaching
you how to Press Your Luck without becoming

the Weakest Link. In other words, how knowing
simple probability can help you win fabulous

prizes on daytime television. In a few weeks,
I ll be appearing in the studio audience of

Let s Make a Deal, a classic game show from
the 1960s that was revived in 2009 when the

entertainment industry officially ran out
of creativity. Now, I won t know if I m actually

going to be a contestant until I get there,
but it pays to come in prepared. Oh, and if

you re wondering why people are dressed like
Chef Boyardee, remember that this is TV, so

if they re going to give you something, gosh
darn it they ve got to humiliate you in front

of millions of people watching from home first!
So, if you ve never seen the show before,

the premise is that the host walks around
the studio audience giving away prizes: money,

mystery boxes, whatever, and then offers contestants
the choice to either keep what they have or

trade it for something hidden behind a curtain.
One tends to be a nice prize, while the other

is an ostrich, an adult male in an oversized
crib, or some other creature you don t really

want to keep in your back yard. These joke
prizes are called Zonks. At the end of the

game, the top winners are presented with three
doors. Hidden behind one is the big prize

of the day, while the other two hide more
Zonks. So, let s assume I go to the show and

get to select one of the three final doors.
Behind one is a brand new puce-green kitchen

set straight out of the Johnson-era while
behind the other two are donkeys or some other

beast of burden. I choose a door, say door
1, at which point the host opens one of the

doors I didn t pick to reveal a donkey. He
then says that I can change my door if I want

to. Assuming I want a vomit-colored kitchen
set, should I switch or stay? Does it even

make a difference? It seems like it shouldn
t matter, right? With only two doors left,

my odds seem to be 50-50, one door hiding
a hideous Frigidair and the other holding

my future pet burro, Bruce. But think again.
At the beginning of the game, I had a 1/3

chance of choosing correctly and a 2/3 chance
of choosing a Zonk, at which point the host

always opens a door with a donkey. If I chose
the car initially and then switch, well I

get my ass handed to me, literally. But if
I chose a donkey in the first round and then

switch, I m guaranteed to win, since the other
donkey has already been revealed. Thus, with

my first choice, I m hoping to choose a donkey.
Since my odds of choosing a donkey at the

beginning of the game was 2/3, by switching,
I now have a 2/3 chance of walking home with

a refrigerator that ll make the EPA tremble
in fear. In other words, choosing to switch

always maximizes your chance of winning. If
you re still confused, think about it with

100 doors: 99 donkeys and one kitchen set.
You pick a door. Obviously, you have a 1/100

chance of choosing correctly, which isn t
very likely. But then the host, who knows

exactly where the prize is, opens 98 doors
with donkeys before offering you the chance

to switch. The odds that the kitchen set is
behind your door is still 1/100, but because

the host knowingly cut down the field to one
other specially-selected door, the odds are

99/100 that by switching, you ll win. It may
seem like sticking with your door is the right

choice, especially now that you re so close
to winning, but in actuality, you re no closer

than when you originally started. This situation
is actually a famous probability problem named

the Monty Hall Problem, named after Let s
Make a Deal s first and most famous host,

which leaves me with just one more question:
How was this color ever in fashion? The 60s

were a weird time, my friends. But no game
show marathon would be complete without a

trip to the granddaddy of daytime gamery,
the highlight of every elementary student

s sickday, the Price is Right, specifically,
the game that everyone loves to see PLINKO!

102 pegs, 5 chips, $50,000 on the line. Drop
a chip, win the amount of the slot it lands

in. Elegant, addicting, and impossible as
fu**. You see, the game has been a part of

the show since 1983, and yet, for as many
times as it s been played, no one has ever

earned the maximum prize. How could they considering
it s a game where you randomly drop tokens

down a pachinko board? So is there any way
to have the odds be ever in your favor? OF

COURSE, but only with the help of the sixth,
and sadly forgotten Planeteer, Math! (Earth,

fire, wind, water, heart) MATH! Oh come on,
it s no just as lame as Heart power! Here

s a diagram of the board. Though there are
a total of 102 pegs on the board, a chip will

only hit twelve on its way to the bottom.
Assuming that at each peg, the chip is equally

likely to go either left or right, where should
a contestant drop their chip to have the best

chance of landing in $10,000? Let s start
with slot 5, right in the middle and directly

above the $10,000 space. If the chip is going
to earn us the most money, it ll need to travel

left six times and right six times, in no
particular order. To figure out the probability

of this happening, we can use what s known
as the binomial distribution. This is the

formula, which is one of those intimidating
math formulas that aren t so bad if you work

through them slowly. This top number represents
the number of trials, or in our case 12 for

the number of pegs our chip will hit. This
bottom number is the number of times we need

it to go left. Since we re assuming the chip
has an equal likelihood of going left or right,

the probability is for each, which goes here
and here. And finally, this is how many times

we want it to go left, and this is how many
times we want it to go right. Through some

boring calculations, we find that the probability
of it landing in the middle if dropped in

the middle is about 22.56%, or about 1/5 of
the time. Not bad, but can we do better? Take

a look at what happens if you try dropping
it in either slot 4. We would need it to go

left five times and right seven. Plugging
it into our equation gives us about 19.34%,

so significantly less. Slot six would be the
same since the board is symmetrical. And the

odds continue to decrease as we move away
from the center. In short, the Plinko board

is a type of normal distribution, or bell
curve, where more things wind up towards the

center than either extreme. So, our best strategy
is to drop it into the center slot. That said,

what are the odds we walk away with the grand
prize of $50,000? When determining the odds

of multiple events all happening at the same
time, you multiply their probabilities of

happening together. Thus, getting all 5 chips
into the $10,000 slot means 22.56 to the fifth

power or .0584%. It s no wonder no one has
ever officially won the game! With odds that

low, you re more likely to see Michael Bay
direct an Oscar-winning art film. So, today

s episode may not guarantee you a win, but
the next time you re in an audience and told

to Come on down, remember your math, loyal
theorists, and you may just be lucky enough

to go home with a grill shaped like a large
green egg. Now if you ll excuse me, I have

a strange urge to go spay and neuter my cat.
But hey, that s just a theory. A game show

theory. Thanks for watching! h}p* h}p* gd?d
h'u- Episode 37: Game Show Theory Matthew

Episode 37: Game Show Theory Title Microsoft

comments.author: Xander IsAwesome

comments.text:
I don't agree. Your odds are determined based on combined circumstances

Lets break it down by percentage per choice:

D1(Donkey)
D2(Donkey)
D3(Car) 

Player 1 chooses door number 1 and the host reveals door number 2 to have a 
donkey behind it Thus taking door number 2 out of the game. 

New choice
D1(Donkey)
D3(Car)

Now the odds are 1 out of 2, if you decide to pick a door at random.


Probability is based on individual circumstance. You now have a one in two 
chance of choosing a donkey. The difference here, is that you don't have an 
extra donkey. Your odds of choosing a car have increased to 1 out of 2 
regardless of which choice you made previously. By staying the same you 
have the same chance of winning your car as you do by switching.﻿
comments.author: Zach's Playing Video Games

comments.text:

experiments. The odds in real life are 1/3 staying vs 2/3 switching.
comments.author: babayetu1000

comments.text:
+Zach's Playing Video Games Think about it like this
D1 - 1/3
D2 - 1/3
D3 - 1/3
By picking D1, you pick a 1/3 chance. When the host opens D3, and it has 
the goat, D3 is eliminated and it's 1/3 is transferred over to D2, giving 
it a 2/3 chance. *Mathematically* speaking, switching would be to your 
advantage, but *practically* speaking, the chances are 50/50.
comments.author: Lamfp Dewd

comments.text:
+Zach's Playing Video Games 
Player chooses D1 and switches - wins
Player chooses D2 and switches - wins
Player chooses D3 and switches - loses

Of the 3 possible scenarios switching wins in 2 of them

comments.author: Christopher Gaming

comments.text:
If the board is TRULY random - meaning that each chip has an equal chance 
of landing in any of the nine slots at the bottom - the probability of 
winning $50,000 is 1 in 59,049 or less than 0.02%.

But there are ALSO the odds of even GETTING the five chips.  You're given 
one and must win each of the other four by determining if a price of a 
small prize has the first number or last number right.  That's a 1 in 2 for 
each of four prizes...or 1 in 16 of getting all four right.  So...the true 
chances of a) getting all five chips and b) getting each chip into $10,000 
on a truly randomized board is...1 in 944,784!  That's just over 0.001%!

Bottom line: odds are exceedingly good that Plinko! will NEVER be won!  
That ain't no theory...that's FACT!﻿

comments.text:
Not quite understanding the monty hall problem here. If you pick a door, 
then you are shown one gag you are still left with 2 doors that you have no 
clue what is behind them. The one gag door has no effect on the two 
remaining closed doors and by having the option to switch you are still 
choosing between two closed doors. It's 50/50 no matter what, unless the 
revealed zonk door somehow magically changes what's behind the door you 
already chose 2/3rds of the time.﻿
comments.author: Epic Furry

comments.text:
Your making wrong assumptions about the probabilities. The key to why the 
probability isn't 50/50 is that the Show Host doesn't choose a door 
randomly to remove but has to specifically reveal an unchosen door with a 
zonk. He is not allowed to reveal the door that you chose and he is not 
allowed to reveal the prize. These conditions are what remove any 
randomness or independent probability that would cause the remaining 
probability to remain 50/50. The video explains the remaining maths and 
logic behind it but the seemingly unintuitive logic stems from these 
conditions.

comments.author: anorack marcolin

comments.text:
Here's another way to look at things:
100 doors, 99 goats, 1 car.
1-in-100 (or 1%) chance of picking the car first time with 99-in-100 (99%) 
chance of picking a goat first time.
The host knows that Door #58 is the car and you picked Door #24 at the 
start of the round.

For each door the host opens that is not #58 or #24 the probability the 
door you picked has the car is still 1% but the probability the car is 
behind one of the other doors raises continually until you're brought down 
to two final doors - Door #24, your initial pick & Door #58.
At the start of the round each door has 1% chance of being a car and 99% 
chance of being a goat, now things have boiled down to a choice between 
Door #24 (Stick) & Door #58 (Swap), the probability of Door #58 being the 
car (and the host KNOWS it is) has risen to 99% whilst you still have a 1% 
chance of Door #24 having the car.

If you swap from Door #24 to Door #58 at this point your odds of picking 
the car have jumped from 1% to 99%, and once the host opens either Door #24 
to reveal a goat (it always had a 99% chance of being a goat from the start 
of the round) or Door #58 to reveal the car, by swapping to Door #58 - *YOU 
WIN!*
comments.author: AEon Tokusatsu Reviews

comments.text:
If that were true then 1/2 + 1/3 would be 1 so you cant be right. The odds 
of winning + the odds of losing by definition have to be 1.

Each door is 1/3 so sticking with a door by definition is 1/3. 1- 1/3 = 2/3 
no matter how you want to solve this therefore you win 2/3 of the time when 
you switch. All that is left is to understand why.

I have found the best way to explain this is by changing the game in a way 
that makes it look like I changed the game mechanics when I really didn't.

In this "new" game the host does not open a door. You pick 1 door and then 
if you want you can pick both other doors instead. At this point everyone 
would agree that getting to open 2 doors has a 2/3 chance of winning.

Well, this is actually exactly the same game.

All the host does in the original game is open 1 of your 2 doors for you.

In both games when you switch you end up with 2 doors open, neither of 
which is the door you started with.

In the end this all comes down to the very simple question, do you want to 
stick with the 1/3 group or move to the 2/3 group.

comments.author: MagusThePsycho

comments.text:
Actually, the probability of winning the maximum prize in Plinko is even 
worse than PDP suggests. His distribution is correct, but he doesn't 
include the fact that you have to earn 4 of the chips before you can place 
them on the board. With 4 chip to earn (the 5th is a freebie) and a 50/50 
chance to earn each chip it's much worse. Odds of 0.5 ^ 4 to earn the chips 
(50% chance for each of 4 chips) and you have a 0.0625 chance to have all 5 
chips...or 1 in 16. Then multiply that by PDP's 0.0584 and you have a 
0.365% chance, or 1 in 274 at best...much worse than the 1 in 17 (0.0584) 
suggested.﻿

comments.text:
.0584% is actually .000584 because you have to divide by 100 to get rid of 
the percent sign. It's actually 1 in 1712 times 1 in 16, equals a total 
probability of 1 in 27,392.

comments.author: Jools Stoo

comments.text:
The binomial distribution only works if each outcome is independent from 
the previous, but in the Plinko machine if the chip goes in one direction 
for a while, it's going to keep going in that direction (intertia, if it's 
been going left for 3 pegs, it's probably going to keep going left). Using 
binomial distribution would only be applicable in an environment with no 
inertia, but that's just my theory :)﻿
comments.author: Akshata P

comments.text: +Akshata P but thats just your theory, a fan theory
comments.author: Enis Spahiu

comments.text: That's interesting to consider actually, thanks.
comments.author: Akshata P

comments.text:
+Akshata P Although your statement is essentially correct, there is one 
observation I would make.  The inertial effect is not so significant as one 
might think, even though it can be a significant factor (bear with me).  
Although it will pick up inertia (it will slide right across multiple pins 
pretty rapidly under inertia), if it builds up inertia it will also 
ricochet off of a side pin, acting as a counterforce that generally causes 
it to fall the other way (yes, I watched The Price is Right as a very young 
child and I remember it).  I am not prepared to tell you how the two forces 
interrelate, but there are counterveiling forces to inertia.  Although a 
binomial distribution isn't going to be a properly accurate description, 
the chance of counterveiling force makes for some degree of functional 
independence, perhaps (though not likely) sufficient to render it 
equivalent to independence.

comments.text:
+MegaSupernova888 Lol...nope.  Your logic is right, but you're missing the 
obvious.  Yes, your second choice would be 50% if it were an independent 
event.  Since the revealed door is always a zonk, you presume the first 
choice to be irrelevant.  But they CANNOT reveal the door you choose. 
 Therefore, once they eliminate the first zonk door, you HAD a 66% chance 
to pick a zonk in round 1.  Round 2 is not a new event.  If you picked the 
prize in round 1 (33% chance), and you change...you lose.  However, the 
odds are that you picked a zonk (66%) so by changing, you win.  Its not a 
guarantee obviously....but it is NOT a 50/50 shot, because it is NOT 2 
separate events.  If you can't understand from there....then just realize 
that life is always more difficult for stupid people, and brace for the 
worst.

comments.author: Nathan Zeligman

comments.text:
+Nathan Zeligman But it is dependent on the first... If you have a 1/100 
chance of picking correctly the first time and do nothing, the second 
choice doesn't matter. HOWEVER, if you have a 1/100 chance of picking 
correctly, then 98 wrong choices are eliminated, your choice from the first 
problem is still relevant; back then you could have picked any of the 98 
other incorrect doors. Thus, switching gives you a 99/100 chance of being 
correct, because they purposely leave the correct choice behind.

The only way these choices would be independent of one another is if you 
were talking about a game where they disregard the first choice (99/100 of 
getting it wrong) and take you to a separate game board with 2 doors you've 
never seen before.

The point of the big reveal is that it gives you new information; it's 
telling you what you didn't know before, that 98 of those other choices 
were wrong. It's way more likely that, if two choices from the original 
problem remain, that your choice was wrong as well if there's only one 
correct choice.

I hope this helps! :D If not, I'd be glad to explain it more. It's a great 
problem that, when you understand it, lets you see probability in a whole 
new light.
comments.author: MegaSupernova888

comments.text:
+Parth Kotak if the probability of the second choice was dependant on the 
first it would be greater. But the second choice is INDEPENDENT of the 
first choice, making whichever door you chose first irrelevant. Therefore 
it is absolutely a 50% chance.

comments.text:
I think I get it. Basically the probability works because the likely hood 
you chose a zonk in the first place was 66% to begin with. So most likely 
you're on a zonk with the one you picked. After the other one that's a zonk 
is revealed, you increase your chance of getting the good prize because you 
likely picked a bad one to begin with. The odds go in your favor when the 
other bad prize and where it is has been eliminated from your choice.

The reason it doesn't "reset" is because it was high that you chose a zonk 
to begin with. That doesn't change when the other one is revealed.

I had a hard time wrapping my head around this one till I thought of the 
66% being against you until the other place of a bad prize was revealed.
I still have some issues, I suppose my brain is just not oriented to think 
this way. I felt like it resets, but it doesn't because your odds were not 
equal to begin with.

It's a great play on human psychology too. We like to stick pridefully with 
our instincts, even though gut feelings are usually wrong.

All gambling, shows and anything having to do with winning are stacked up 
so you're likely to be the loser.

Humans aren't good with probability in the face of dopamine based promise, 
or the idea of reward. That's why gambling works.﻿
comments.author: Vixx “Sinvanor” Celacea

comments.text:
Let's make this perfectly clear: the prizes NEVER MOVE during the game. 
Let's say that, after the host opens up one of the doors, someone backstage 
randomly switches the remaining two prizes. THEN you would have a 50-50 
chance of being right. But that's not what happens.

So, say you pick a door. Because there are three doors with an equal 
likelihood of being right, you now have a 1/3 chance of having picked the 
correct door. Then the host intentionally opens a wrong door that you 
didn't choose. Now here's the key: because the prizes haven't moved, you 
still have only a 1/3 chance of having picked the correct door. The door 
the host opened was never the correct door, which is why he opened it. The 
correct door hasn't changed at all. Therefore, the door you picked is 
correct if and only if it was correct before a door was opened; the 
probability of that is 1/3. That leaves a 2/3 chance that the third door is 
the correct one.

If you're still not convinced, think of it this way. Suppose that, instead 
of opening a door, the host told you that you could take either the prize 
behind your door, or take both of the prizes behind the other two doors 
(minus any farm animals, of course). Obviously you would choose the latter 
option because that maximizes your odds of winning. But remember that only 
one of the doors has a meaningful prize, which means that if it is indeed 
behind one of the other two doors, the other one definitely has an animal 
behind it. That means that if you do choose to take two prizes, there is a 
100% chance that at least one of them is an animal.

Believe it or not, this scenario and the actual Monty Hall Problem work on 
exactly the same principle. In the real game, by switching your choice, you 
are essentially choosing to take both of the prizes behind the other two 
doors, minus the animal you have already seen. Because your action of 
choosing a door left two doors behind, there is a 100% chance that one of 
them has an animal behind it. The only difference is that the host is 
taking that animal out of the equation by opening up one of those two 
doors. But the odds that the prize is behind the other door are still the 
same as they started.﻿
comments.author: PlutoTheSecond

comments.text:
Actually, you HAVE to add the lost chance to the other door. You're 
thinking about it wrong. It's not the other door you didn't choose whose 
probability doesn't change, it's the door you did choose. Think of it this 
way: suppose the winning prize is hidden behind door #1. There are three 
possible scenarios at the beginning: the contestant chooses door #1, door 
#2, or door #3. Each of these scenarios is equally likely, so they each 
have a probability of 1/3. If the contestant chose door #1, the host will 
randomly open either door #2 or door #3 because they are both wrong; these 
two events are equally likely and thus have a probability of 1/6 each (out 
of 1/3). If the contestant chose door #2, the host MUST open door 
#3 because it is wrong and door #1 is correct; the probability of this is 
1/3. If the contestant chose door #3, the host MUST open door #2 because it 
is wrong and door #1 is correct; the probability of this is 1/3. Now we 
have four scenarios, two of which require that the contestant chose door #1 
and each have a probability of 1/6, and the other two require that the 
contestant didn't choose door #1 and each have a probability of 1/3. In 
every scenario, door #1 is correct, so the probability that the contestant 
has chosen the correct door is 1/6 + 1/6 = 1/3. There's no "Schrodinger's 
cat" effect here; the fifty-fifty odds are just an illusion. It's trickery. 
This is what makes this such a famous probability question, because the 
fact that you have only two doors left no matter what makes you THINK you 
have fifty-fifty odds when in fact you don't.
comments.author: PlutoTheSecond

comments.author: Argedon

comments.text:
For the Monty Hall Problem if you didn't understand:
So let's say you pick one curtain out of three. The host reveals a 
different curtain, which is a loser prize. Now there are two curtains, but 
your odds of getting the grand prize aren't 50/50.
See, in the beginning there were three curtains. Two losing prizes, one 
winning. So the odds of picking a winning prize was 1/3, and the odds of 
picking a losing prize were 2/3.
You had a better chance of picking a losing prize than a winning prize. You 
only had a 1/3 chance of picking the winning prize, so switching would give 
you better odds at actually winning the grand prize.
By switching curtains, you now have a 2/3 chance of picking the winning 
prize.﻿

comments.text:
No matter how many times I see the Monty Hall problem presented, it still 
shocks me how many people get it wrong, and seem to be unable to understand 
the actual answer.  I just don't get it.  It seems pretty simple to me.

you make your choice when there are three doors; you have a 1/3 chance of 
choosing the prize door and 2/3 chance of choosing a zonk when you make 
your choice.  even after the host reveals and removes one zonk, it is still 
more likely that the door you first chose is a zonk.  so you win more often 
if you always switch.  Why is that so hard to understand, I'm honestly 
asking?  When my economics class did the problem only a small part of the 
class got it right, and when Car Talk used the question as their weekly 
puzzler, they got more letters from people telling them they were wrong 
than with any other question they asked.  There just seems to be something 
about THIS problem that scrambles peoples' minds.  ﻿
